item.title: Setup
item.description: Making your own Quartz Setting up Quartz requires a basic understanding of git. If you are unfamiliar, this resource is a great place to start!

item.title: Editing Content in Quartz
item.description: Editing Quartz runs on top of Hugo so all notes are written in Markdown. Folder Structure Here’s a rough overview of what’s what.

item.title: Obsidian Vault Integration
item.description: Setup Obsidian is the preferred way to use Quartz. You can either create a new Obsidian Vault or link one that your already have.

item.title: Preview Changes
item.description: If you’d like to preview what your Quartz site looks like before deploying it to the internet, here’s exactly how to do that!

item.title: Deploying Quartz to the Web
item.description: Hosting on GitHub Pages Quartz is designed to be effortless to deploy. If you forked and cloned Quartz directly from the repository, everything should already be good to go!
Sets
Availability Zones Availability zones (AZz) are basically just one or multiple physical [[Data Center|data centers]] in a [[Region|region]]. Availability zones

AWS CloudFront is a CDN service to help you serve cached static and dynamic content to users with minimal latency. It’s great because you can trust in its very high availability, and it also handles things like DDoS attacks and other network attacks well.
![[Data center.png]] Data centers are very large physical buildings that are dedicated to housing the computers that form the [[Cloud Computing|cloud]].

AWS edge locations are [[Data Center|data centers]] owned by trusted 3rd party, called an AWS Partner, that uses [[CloudFront]]. Together, the edge locations form the edge network between AWS and end users.
Regions A region is literally a geographic region which contains 1 or more [[Availability Zone|availability zones]]. AWS ensures that there are a minimum of 2 AZs in every region.

Cloud computing describes the usage of a network of remote computers managed by [[Cloud Provider|cloud providers]] to handle computing tasks like storing/serving files, running web servers, training machine learning models, etc.
Cloud providers are just companies who have set up this big network of remote computers and give you reasonable prices for running computing tasks on their computers.

Generators are just functions which, when invoked, will give you a single value from a list of values. They’re stateful functions which return the next value in a list of values for each successive invocation.
An iterator is an object that lets you loop through an iterable, usually by invoking, implicitly or explicitly, a next method.
Stack TODO.
SaaS
TODO.
A type system is a set of rules defined by a programming language specification that assigns a type to every variable, expression, function, and possibly other things beyond those.
Vue.js Vue.js is …
TODO. There’s also [[TypeScript]]. Prototypes TODO. Rest Operator TODO. Generators TODO.
Dunder Methods TODO.

TypeScript is a programming language made by Microsoft that is superset of [[JavaScript]]. The reason that TypeScript exists is to make complex JavaScript projects more maintainable and less error-prone by introducing a [[Type System#Static Typing|static]] and [[Type System#Strong Typing|strong]] type system.

item.title: CJK + Latex Support (测试)
item.description: Chinese, Japanese, Korean Support 几乎在我们意识到之前，我们已经离开了地面。 우리가 그것을 알기도 전에 우리는 땅을 떠났습니다. 私たちがそれを知るほぼ前に、私たちは地面を離れていました。 Latex Block math works with two dollar signs $$.

item.title: Configuration
item.description: Configuration Quartz is designed to be extremely configurable. You can find the bulk of the configuration scattered throughout the repository depending on how in-depth you’d like to get.

item.title: Custom Domain
item.description: Registrar This step is only applicable if you are using a custom domain! If you are using a <YOUR-USERNAME>.github.io domain, you can skip this step.

item.title: Ignoring Notes
item.description: Quartz Ignore Edit ignoreFiles in config.toml to include paths you’d like to exclude from being rendered. 1 2 3 4 5 6 .

item.title: Quartz Philosophy
item.description: “[One] who works with the door open gets all kinds of interruptions, but [they] also occasionally gets clues as to what the world is and what might be important.

item.title: Showcase
item.description: Want to see what Quartz can do? Here are some cool community gardens :) Quartz Documentation (this site!) Jacky Zhao’s Garden AWAGMI Intern Notes Shihyu’s PKM Chloe’s Garden SlRvb’s Site Course notes for Information Technology Advanced Theory Brandon Boswell’s Garden Siyang’s Courtyard If you want to see your own on here, submit a Pull Request adding yourself to this file!

item.title: Troubleshooting and FAQ
item.description: Still having trouble? Here are a list of common questions and problems people encounter when installing Quartz. While you’re here, join our Discord :)

item.title: Updating
item.description: Haven’t updated Quartz in a while and want all the cool new optimizations? On Unix/Mac systems you can run the following command for a one-line update!
